title-group.article-title: Damage detection in a woven-fabric composite laminate using time-reversed Lamb wave

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Aerospace Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India
2Department of Aerospace Engineering, Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology, Thiruvananthapuram, India

author-notes.corresp: Mira Mitra, Department of Aerospace Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai 400076, India Email: mira@aero.iitb.ac.in

abstract.p: Time reversibility is the process in which a response signal recorded at a receiver location is reversed in time and transmitted back through the receiver to the original transmitter location. In the absence of any defect or damage in the path between the transmitter and the receiver locations, theoretically, the signal received back at the original transmitter location (reconstructed signal) is identical to the original input signal. Therefore, differences in the transmitted and reconstructed signals are an indication of the possibility of a defect being present. An experimental study of a baseline-free damage detection technique using time reversibility of Lamb wave for a woven-fabric composite laminate is presented in this article. The initial part of the study is aimed towards obtaining the best possible reconstruction of the input signal by tuning various parameters of interest, including an experimental study of the frequency-dependent attenuation of Lamb wave modes (amplitude tuning). A finite element simulation has also been carried out to study the effect of amplitude tuning. Finally, the time-reversal concept is used to detect damage in woven composite laminates without using any information from the undamaged structure. In this study, a small block mass bonded to the surface, surface erosion and local impact are considered as representative of different types of damage. The results obtained show that the Lamb wave technique using time-reversal concept identifies correctly the presence of damage in woven-fabric composite laminates, thus providing a basis for baseline-free damage detection in composite structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Guided elastic waves have attracted the attention of many researchers in view of their applicability to structural health monitoring (SHM) of thin-walled structures such as primary structural components of an aircraft wing box.1,2 In these methods, information about damage is obtained by monitoring the changes in the characteristics of an elastic wave arising from its interaction with the damage. Lamb waves are the most common form of such elastic waves used for damage detection. Contrary to conventional methods, their higher speed and lower attenuation, along with ease of excitation and recording using inexpensive instrumentation,3 make them an ideal basis for in situ SHM systems for aircraft structures. This article deals with the problem of damage detection in woven composite laminates using Lamb wave propagation with lead zirconate titanate (PZT) wafers as transducers and receivers.

Continuously changing operational and environmental conditions during the service life of composite structures cause large variations in their dynamic characteristics, making it difficult to predict damage by monitoring changes from the baseline (undamaged) signatures. This, along with the dispersive and multi-modal nature of Lamb wave propagation, results in significant technical difficulties in interpreting the signal changes between baseline and test data. In order to reduce the effects of dispersion and to make the Lamb wave damage detection techniques baseline free, researchers extended the concept of time reversal known from general acoustics4 to Lamb wave propagation.5 According to time reversibility in acoustics, an input signal can be reconstructed at the source point if an output signal recorded at another point is reversed in time domain and transmitted back to the same source point along the same path, as long as there is no change in the constitution of the material medium along the path (time reversibility property). They showed that the time-reversal concept (TRC) is also applicable to Lamb wave propagation.

Subsequently, considerable research has been carried out to extend and apply the concept to detect damage in thin plate structures, as the presence of damage can result in a localized change in the properties of the material media along the path and the time-reversibility property will not be preserved. In the presence of damage in the wave path, there could be considerable difference between the input wave and the reconstructed wave obtained after time reversal. Several studies6–13 have explored the potential of time reversibility of Lamb wave for development of baseline-free SHM schemes for damage detection, mostly in thin metallic plates. Some of these researchers7,8,11 have studied the time reversibility–based technique for development of baseline-free damage detection in composite structures. The complexities associated with Lamb waves, including high wave speeds, existence of multiple wave modes and dispersive nature of the modes, added to the inhomogeneity and anisotropy of composite structures, make the development of such techniques for application to fibre-reinforced laminated composite structures even more challenging. As a potential damage detection tool for composite laminates, Lamb wave techniques based on TRC need further exploration to improve confidence in their use in practice. The aim of this article is to add to the state of art through further understanding of the TRC-based damage detection scheme for woven-fabric composite laminates through numerical simulation as well as through an experimental study.

Park et al.7 studied the applicability of TRC for Lamb wave propagation in a quasi-isotropic thin composite laminate through a numerical simulation limited to the
A
0
mode, based on Mindlin plate theory, to show the effect of frequency dependence of the time-reversal operator on the reconstruction of the input signal, referred to as amplitude tuning. They conducted experiments using a narrow band tone burst excitation along with wavelet-based techniques to isolate the
A
0
mode and reduce noise at frequencies away from the driving frequency. The experimentally obtained reconstruction for the
A
0
mode after signal processing was found to be well matched with the input signal. Giurgiutiu14 studied the variation of amplitude of different Lamb wave modes with frequency and suggested that required modes can be tuned by varying frequency. Sohn et al.8 applied the techniques of Ref.[7], based on excitation of the antisymmetric Lamb wave mode and its isolation in the forward and time-reversed response signals, to successfully detect the location and estimate the size of impact damage in a quasi-isotropic laminate. Park et al.9 have extended the theoretical study to include both the
A
0
and
S
0
modes to study the effect of multiple modes (modal dispersion) and reflections from boundaries on the reconstruction after time reversal, in an undamaged aluminium plate, using a finite element (FE) numerical simulation, followed by an experimental verification. Their main finding was that the reconstructed signal consisted of a well-differentiated main peak (referred to as main mode), with sidebands arising from the modal dispersion and reflections and the original input signal matched well with the main mode of the reconstructed signal.

In this article, damage detection is carried out by time-reversed Lamb wave (TRLW) in a thin woven-fabric composite laminate with PZT wafers as transducers, for several representative damage types, through analysis of the reconstructed signal obtained experimentally. The transducer parameters and signal generation as well as processing parameters have been chosen on the basis of results from an earlier study12 by the authors of this article on TRLWs in an aluminium plate. The nature of frequency dependency of Lamb wave amplitude response in the woven-fabric composite laminate is investigated through experiments as well as numerical simulations and compared with that of aluminium over a wide frequency range. Next, experiments are performed on damaged plates by creating various kinds of artificial but representative damage in woven composite laminates to observe their effects on the distortion of the reconstructed signal and consequent mismatch with the original input signal. Through these experiments, it is shown that different kinds of damage in a woven-fabric composite laminate can be detected using the TRC and their effect on the reconstructed signals can be quantified. For the sake of brevity, the technique used will be referred to as the TRLW technique in the rest of this article.

sec.title: Dispersion plot of the woven-fabric composite laminate
sec.p: In order to design the experiment effectively and to select the central frequency of excitation with minimum dispersion, the dispersion plot was obtained using spectral FE method.15

The woven-fabric composite was considered as an equivalent single orthotropic layer for this purpose. The governing elastodynamic equations for two-dimensional (2D) orthotropic media are given as follows

The displacement field was approximated using discrete Fourier transform (equation (3)) and the partial differential equations were transformed to ordinary differential equations in
z

where
ω
is the discrete angular frequency and
ζ
is the discrete horizontal wave number. The spectral layer element was formed as shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Spectral layer element.

sec.p:
The element dynamic stiffness matrix was formed using the traction-free boundary conditions at
z = 0
and
h
as given in equation (4)

The admissible Lamb wave modes were traced corresponding to the singular values of the dynamic stiffness matrix for different
ω − ζ
combinations. The dispersion plot obtained is shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Dispersion plot of woven-fabric composite.

sec.title: Experimental study of TRLW in a woven-fabric composite laminate
Experimental setup
sec.p: The experimental setup included a Tektronix AFG 3021B signal generator and a Tektronix TDS 1002B digital storage oscilloscope, as shown in Figures 3 and 4. The signal generator was programmed to generate the required narrow band tone burst input pulse. The Tektronix TDS 1002B digital storage oscilloscope was used for data acquisition of the response signals and the digital data were transferred to a computer for further offline processing. The experiments were performed on a 2-mm thick glass fibre–reinforced plastic (GFRP) composite laminate with five layers of plain weave glass fabric (modulus of elasticity 28.3 GPa, Poisson’s ratio 0.32, fibre volume fraction 0.6 and density 2.1 g/cc). Damage detection using Lamb waves involves several complexities and therefore the experiments need to be designed carefully. The wave and transducer parameters were optimally selected, as per guidelines emerging from the earlier parametric experimental study on aluminium plates by the authors12 to minimize the effect of two features, namely, dispersion and multi-modal wave propagation. The wafer-type PZT transducers (material type SP-5H) of size 7 mm2 with 0.5-mm thickness were used for actuation and sensing of the Lamb wave. They were bonded to the plate using a commercially available cyanoacrylate adhesive. An eight-cycle burst sine wave with amplitude modulated by a Hanning window was used as the input signal.

caption.p: Picture of the experimental setup.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.
Schematic of the experimental setup.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.p:
The PZT patch transducers were bonded to the laminate (
1000 × 1000 × 2
mm
3
) with a separation of 200 mm to avoid the mixing of the first two Lamb wave modes (
S
0
and
A
0
) and the reflected waves from the specimen boundary. Figure 5 illustrates a typical input signal given to one of the PZT patches (actuator) and the corresponding response at the other PZT patch (sensor) in terms of normalized voltage. In all the plots in which signal time histories are reported in this article, the abscissa is datapoint number, with the time interval between consecutive points (sampling time) being 1 µs.

caption.p: Input and output signals.

sec.p: The recorded signals were filtered through a low-pass Butterworth filter to reduce the effects of high-frequency electromagnetic noise. Furthermore, the input signal and the reconstructed input signal are of different magnitudes. Thus, to compare the shapes of input signals and the reconstructed input signals, all signals were scaled to a magnitude of 1 by dividing the voltage values of all the datapoints of a signal by the maximum value in the signal data stream. To quantify the similarity or difference between the reconstructed and input signals, a correlation factor, given by the following expression from Ref.[12], is used here
where

x
¯
and
y
¯
are the mean values of the data sets
x
j
and
y
j
respectively, and
n
being the total number of datapoints in each set.
The error of reconstructions was also evaluated using the root-mean-square deviation (RMSD) reported in Ref.[6]

sec.title: Test frequency
sec.p: The frequency selection was done by considering velocity dispersion and amplitude tuning. Although TRLW minimizes the effect of velocity dispersion, the effect of amplitude variation with frequency becomes worse as it distorts the signal twice: first, when the forward signal is sent to the sensor and again when the recorded signal is time reversed and sent back to the initial actuator.9,12 This effect is unavoidable as the excited signal will always have a finite frequency bandwidth. Previous research has shown that this effect can be minimized by carefully selecting a frequency bandwidth where the amplitude variation is minimal.12

Therefore, the amplitude tuning or dependency of the response amplitude on the frequency in the composite laminate was studied experimentally before applying TRLW to damage detection. The plot showing the variation of amplitude response with the frequency components of the Lamb wave was experimentally generated by calculating the ratios of magnitude of fast Fourier transform (FFT) components of the response signal and the corresponding components of the input signal at each frequency. The complete amplitude tuning plot was obtained by carrying out the experiment at a number of discrete central frequencies of the Lamb wave packet over the frequency range of the dispersion plot. Figures 6 and 7 show the variation of amplitude ratio of
S
0
and
A
0
modes of actuated Lamb wave in an aluminium plate12 and the woven-fabric composite laminate, respectively. It is interesting to note that the nature of amplitude tuning of
S
0
is drastically different in the composite laminate compared to the aluminium plate. In the aluminium plate, the dispersion plot clearly shows only one prominent peak. However, in the case of the woven-fabric composite laminate, there are two peaks in the dispersion plot. This experimental observation has been corroborated by comparing with FE simulation results presented in the following section. Park et al.7,9 have computed the variation of the normalized time-reversal operator of the
A
0
mode versus frequency, for an isotropic thin plate based on Mindlin plate theory, which shows a prominent peak. Compared to this, the experimentally obtained plot in Figure 6 for the
A
0
mode of the aluminium plate, however, does not show a very prominent peak, although this is seen in the case of the composite laminate at the lower end of the frequency range. To the best of the knowledge of the authors, such experimentally obtained plots of the amplitude tuning of the
A
0
and
S
0
Lamb wave modes are not available elsewhere in the literature for direct comparison.

caption.p:
Experimentally measured amplitude tuning of
A
0
and
S
0
modes for 1.6-mm aluminium plate12.

Experimentally measured amplitude tuning of
A
0
and
S
0
modes for 2-mm woven composite laminate.

sec.p:
These plots are important in evolving an experimental procedure to minimize the effect of amplitude variation with frequency. To minimize the effect of amplitude variation with frequency, one should perform experiments within a frequency band where the amplitude tuning or sensitivity to frequency variation is small. An FFT of the signals in Figure 5 showed significant response components over almost a 50-kHz band around the central frequency of the amplitude-modulated burst sine wave packet. The range of frequency for the experiments was selected as 50–100 kHz, as within this band the amplitude variation with frequency of both
S
0
and
A
0
is not very steep comparatively, while their response amplitudes are also not too low (see Figure 7). At higher frequencies, the
S
0
mode shows large response amplitude with substantial variation with frequency, but the
A
0
mode amplitude is very low leading to poor signal-to-noise ratios for the
A
0
mode.

Several experiments were carried out at different frequencies ranging between 50- and 100-kHz band and it was found that for 88-kHz central frequency, best reconstruction of the input signal in terms of
R
is achieved for the PZT transducer size of 7 mm2.

sec.title: Simulation of amplitude tuning of Lamb waves
sec.p: The simulation of Lamb waves was attempted as a transient structural dynamics problem using a 2D FE analysis in ANSYS 13.0©. The FE model included a multi-physics model of the piezoelectric actuator. A plain-strain layer-wise modelling of the plate in the thickness direction was adopted. The five-layer woven-fabric composite material was modelled as an equivalent ten-layer cross-ply configuration with unidirectional laminate. A burn test of the composite specimen was conducted and the fibre volume fraction was ascertained as 0.6. The in-plane elastic modulus in the wave propagation direction and the modulus in the thickness direction were evaluated as 26 and 9 GPa by a lamina analysis using law of mixtures. The elastic modulus of the composite plate was tested in laboratory and found to be in agreement with the cross-ply model adopted. The test value of the elastic modulus was 28.3 GPa.
The composite plate was discretized with eight-noded quadrilateral orthotropic plane elements. The size of the elements and time integration steps were chosen on the basis of the following relations
and

where
L
max
is the maximum size of the element,
λ
min
is the minimum wavelength,
n
min
should be 8–10 for convergence,
Δ t
is the integration time step,
L
min
is the minimum size of the element and
C
is the wave speed.16 The model had 30,014 elements with a size of 0.5 × 0.2 mm2. The element size in the thickness direction was determined by the thickness of the ply, that is, 0.2 mm. The integration time step was taken as 0.208 µs.

The amplitude tuning characteristics of both
S
0
and
A
0
modes were simulated for aluminium (Figure 8) and woven-fabric composite (Figure 9). Figures 8 and 9 show relative amplitude versus frequency. The normalized amplitude is arrived at by taking the ratio of the Fourier transform coefficients of
S
0
and
A
0
modes, respectively, with those of the input wave and normalizing the maximum magnitude to 1.0.

caption.p:
Amplitude tuning of
A
0
and
S
0
modes in 1.6-mm aluminium plate from FE simulations.
FE: finite element.

Amplitude tuning of
A
0
and
S
0
modes in 2-mm woven composite laminate from FE simulations.
FE: finite element.

sec.p: The amplitude tuning of Lamb wave modes is captured qualitatively by the simulation. In the 2D plain-strain FE analysis, the piezoelectric actuator extends throughout the plate in the width direction. This inconsistency with respect to the actual finite size of the actuator patch in the experiment can be a probable reason for the quantitative variation in simulation results. The velocities of both Lamb wave modes obtained from the simulation results match well with the corresponding experimental velocities, as shown in Tables 1 and 2.

caption.p:
Comparison of group velocity of Lamb wave mode
S
0

Comparison of group velocity of Lamb wave mode
A
0

sec.title: Damage detection using TRLW technique
sec.p: The TRLW technique was applied to detect various kinds of representative but artificial damage in the woven-fabric composite laminate. The experiments have been performed on the same laminate by introducing various types of artificial damage at different locations, to study the effect of the damage on signal reconstruction through time reversal. The suitability of using the TRLW as a baseline-free damage detection scheme for composite structure is examined. The representative artificial damage studied here is as follows: (1) circular block mass of 22 mm diameter and 3 mm thickness in the form of a metallic coin pasted between the sensor and the actuator; (2) circular block mass of 22 mm diameter and 2 mm thickness of the same material as the laminate; (3) a circular cavity of 22 mm diameter and 1 mm thickness created by surface removal through machining; (4) impact damage of 30 mm diameter (causing matrix crushing); and (5) impact damage of 40 mm diameter (matrix crushing plus delamination).

According to linear reciprocity of elastodynamics, delamination and crack are sources of non-linear wave scattering.7 Cases (4) and (5) of impact damages studied in the present work involve multiple cracks and delamination and therefore are acting as a source of non-linearity resulting in the breakdown of time reversibility. However, the other three cases of damages, that is, block mass and surface cavity, apparently do not result in non-linearity. In case of these damages, there would be mode conversions of both
A
0
and
S
0
modes due to damage, the refraction and reflection of waves occurring due to the new asymmetric boundary conditions at the location of the damage, possibly resulting in the observed change in reconstructed wave even in the absence of non-linearity. However, further investigation is required for proper understanding of the phenomenon. A similar change in the time-reversed reconstructed wave due to the presence of a block mass is also reported by Sohn and Kim.17

The schematic representations of cases (1) and (2) are given in Figure 14, that of case (3) in Figure 16 and that of cases (4) and (5) in Figure 10. In all the cases, in the forward path, PZT A acts as the actuator and PZT B as sensor. The time-reversed signal is sent from PZT B as actuator and the reconstructed signal is obtained at PZT A.

caption.p: Scheme of laminate with damage through the thickness.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.p:
Figures 11 to 18 show the forward signal of the Lamb wave propagation in the composite laminate without/with damage. It is seen that the different types of damages affect the forward signal in different fashion. Figure 11 shows that in the case of undamaged plate, the
S
0
and
A
0
modes are clearly separated resulting in a well-reconstructed input signal by time reversal. In the case of bonded metallic and composite coins (Figures 12 and 13, respectively), the effect on the forward signals is similar and the distortion and attenuation are higher in the case of metallic coin. In the case of the machined cavity (Figure 15), the individual wave packets of
S
0
and
A
0
modes are not distorted significantly but there is a small wave packet present between
S
0
and
A
0
, which causes distortion of the reconstructed wave packet as shown later in Figure 21. Comparing Figures 17 and 18, the presence of delamination in addition to the matrix crushing completely changes the distortion pattern of the forward signal. In the case of only matrix crushing, both the packets show small distortion with substantial attenuation. In the case of matrix crushing with added delamination, there is further attenuation along with significant elongation of the
A
0
packet. Both these effects distort the reconstructed wave packet, as shown in Figures 24 and 25 later.

caption.p: Forward wave recorded at the sensor (undamaged laminate).
Forward wave recorded at the sensor (laminate with metallic coin).
Forward wave recorded at the sensor (laminate with composite coin).
Scheme of laminate with block mass.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.
Forward wave recorded at the sensor (laminate with cavity).
Scheme of laminate with circular cavity.
PZT: lead zirconate titanate.
Forward wave recorded at the sensor (laminate with matrix crushing).
Forward wave recorded at the sensor (laminate with matrix crushing and delamination).

sec.p:
In order to ensure full reconstruction, the forward signals were truncated only to eliminate edge reflections. Since the laminate is of large dimensions, the forward modes (
S
0
and
A
0
) are well separated from edge reflections. Reconstructions were done with different forward signal truncation time. The fact that the selected forward signals contained all forward modes was asserted by the reconstructions being invariant with truncation time.

sec.title: Reconstruction results with block mass as damage
sec.p: Both metallic and composite discs are attached to the laminate as shown in Figure 14. The reconstructed signals are shown in Figures 19 and 20. Table 3 gives the values of the correlation coefficient and RMSD corresponding to Figures 19 and 20.

caption.p: Reconstructed input signal and original input signal (with composite coin).
Reconstructed input signal and original input signal (with metallic coin).
Similarity between reconstructed input signal and original input signal (with block mass as damage)

fn.p: 2D FE: two-dimensional finite element; RMSD: root mean square deviation.

sec.p: From these experiments, it is observed that the presence of the small bonded blocks can be detected using the TRC of Lamb wave, as the presence of the damage increases the error in the reconstruction from 16.86% to 24.46% in case of composite coin and to a very high value of 52.16% in the case of metallic coin as block masses. The correlation factor also decreases accordingly. It can be noted that in the case of the metallic coin, the distortion of the reconstructed signal is severe, whereas in the case of the composite coin, it is much less. This could be attributed to the significantly more mass and density of the metallic coin than the composite one. The metallic coin introduces a larger lumped mass and results in a sudden density change in the wave propagation path. Interestingly, both the coins affect the forward signal in a similar way.

The 2D FE analysis of wave response of the laminate in the presence of the above damage cases was also carried out using the ANSYS 13.0 model outlined in section ‘Simulation of amplitude tuning of Lamb waves’. The 2D FE results show a very similar trend to the experimental results. The FE results show that the values of correlation factor and RMSD are close to the experimental values. The FE simulation shows a slightly stronger indication of the presence of damage due to the fact that the 2D modelling considers the defect to extend throughout the width of the laminate.

sec.title: Reconstruction results with surface cavity damage
sec.p: In this experiment, a small part of the surface of the laminate is removed by machining to a depth of 1 mm in the shape of 22-mm diameter circle, located centrally in between the two PZT patches, as shown in Figure 16. Figure 21 shows the reconstructed signal in the presence of cavity between the PZT patches along with input signal. The correlation coefficient and RMSD data corresponding to Figure 21 are given in Table 4. It is observed that the presence of surface damage can be detected using the TRC of Lamb wave, as the presence of the damage increases the error in the reconstruction from 18.39% to 29.39%. The correlation factor also decreases accordingly.

caption.p: Reconstructed input signal and original input signal (with surface damage).
Similarity between reconstructed input signal and original input signal (with surface damage)

fn.p: 2D FE: two-dimensional finite element; RMSD: root mean square deviation.

sec.p: In the case of surface cavity, the 2D FE results are also close to the experimental values and show more prominent presence of damage due to the plane-strain modelling.

sec.title: Experiments with impact damage
sec.p: In these experiments, first, a 30-mm diameter area, centrally placed in between the PZT patches, was impacted with hammer with a support from the rear side to cause local crushing of the epoxy matrix and to cause fibre breakage. Then, in the second part, delamination was created around the matrix-crushed area having 40 mm diameter by impacting the surrounding area without support at the rear side of the laminate. Figure 22 shows the local crushing damage and Figure 23 shows the image of local crushing with delamination.

caption.p: Matrix crushing damage.
Matrix crushing with fibre breakage and delamination.

sec.p: Results from the measurements carried out across the impact damage, in Figures 24 and 25 and Table 5, show that the presence of impact damage increases the error in the reconstruction from 11.78% to 25.36% in the case of only matrix crushing and to 26.12% in the case of matrix crushing with delamination. The correlation factor also decreases accordingly. There is very little difference between the two cases in terms of the reconstruction parameter values. Thus, it may be noted that although there is substantial difference in the forward signals in the two cases, this does not translate to a substantial difference in the reconstruction.

caption.p: Reconstructed input signal and original input signal (with matrix crushing as damage).
Reconstructed input signal and original input signal (with matrix crushing and delamination as damage).
Similarity between reconstructed input signal and original input signal (with impact damage)

tr.td: With matrix crushing and delamination as damage

sec.p: In order to keep the reference-free nature of the technique, it is important to ascertain a threshold value for the reconstruction in an undamaged plate in actual experiments. The small variation in the values of correlation and RMSD in the undamaged plate is due to several experimental reasons, such as variation in piezoelectric properties, change in bond thickness and so on, which are yet to be quantified. Repeated experiments in undamaged plate reveal that the minimum value of correlation is greater than 98. So, in the present experiments, a value of 98 for the correlation can be taken as the threshold. Lower values of correlation could be construed as presence of damage. Similarly, a percentage RMSD of 20 could be established as threshold and higher values as indication of the presence of damage.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: An experimental study has been presented to explore the suitability of time reversibility of Lamb wave for baseline-free damage detection in woven-fabric composite laminates. The experiments were carried out on a GFRP woven-fabric laminate using PZT wafers as transducers to generate and detect Lamb wave responses.

From initial experiments it was found that the time reversibility of Lamb wave holds well even in composite materials despite its inherent inhomogeneous nature. The quality of reconstruction, however, depends heavily on the amplitude variation with frequency, as time reversibility minimizes the effects of velocity dispersion but cannot reduce the effect of amplitude variation. It was shown that in TRC the quality of reconstruction depends, to a large extent, on the selection of frequency bandwidth that controls the amplitude tuning. It was also shown, through experimentation and simulation, that the amplitude tuning pattern is fundamentally different in woven composite material from that of an isotropic material like aluminium. This although being an important feature controlling TRC and thereby damage detection using TRC, has not been reported earlier.

In the other set of experiments on damage detection, it was observed that significant distortion in the reconstructed input signal occurred in all the cases of damage considered including attached block mass, surface erosion in the form of a cavity as well as impact damage resulting in matrix crushing with/without delamination. These distortions were quantified by comparing it with the input signal and could be used as a basic form of damage detection tool.

The experimental study with various kinds of damage shows that it is possible to detect the presence of different kinds of damages in the wave propagation path in woven composite laminate without using baseline data, but using time reversibility of Lamb wave. These results show the promise of TRC in developing a baseline-free SHM scheme for composite structures, further reinforcing similar conclusions from earlier research.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This study received the financial support from the Aeronautics Research and Development Board, Government of India (project number 1490).
